title: AI Productivity Transformation Checklist
subtitle: A 30-day, low-risk plan to reclaim your time with AI tools - safely and strategically

blocks.text: Start small, think big. This 30-day plan introduces AI tools gradually, building confidence through quick wins before tackling bigger challenges. Each week builds on the last, creating sustainable habits.

blocks.title: Quick start
blocks.text: Jump to Week 1, Day 1. Complete just one task. Experience the time-saving immediately, then decide if you want to continue with the full program.
This checklist works for any teacher, regardless of tech comfort level. No special software required - just access to free AI assistants like ChatGPT, Claude, or Microsoft Copilot.

blocks.title: Week 1 - Baseline & Quick Wins
blocks.text: Document current pain points, try 3 simple AI tasks, establish safety habits. Goal: Save 2-3 hours this week with basic prompts.

blocks.title: Week 2 - Communication Workflows
blocks.text: Master parent emails, feedback writing, and message polishing. Goal: Cut communication time by 50% while improving quality.

blocks.title: Week 3 - Lesson Planning Systems
blocks.text: Streamline lesson prep, resource creation, and differentiation. Goal: Reduce Sunday planning sessions from 3 hours to 1 hour.

blocks.title: Week 4 - Integration & Scale-Up
blocks.text: Combine multiple workflows, track results, plan continued growth. Goal: Establish sustainable AI-enhanced teaching practice.

blocks.title: Research shows
blocks.text: Teachers who adopt AI gradually (versus all-at-once) report 3x higher satisfaction rates and sustained usage after 6 months.
Before starting, capture your current reality. This baseline helps you measure progress and celebrate wins along the way.

items: List 3 tasks you dread doing on Sunday evenings
Note how long you spend on email each day (estimate)
Identify your biggest time-waster during the week
Record how many hours you work beyond contracted time
Write down one task that makes you feel rushed or stressed
Note which admin tasks prevent you from focusing on teaching
Identify where you feel you're 'reinventing the wheel' regularly

blocks.title: Measurement matters
blocks.text: Take a photo of your completed baseline checklist. You'll be amazed at the progress when you review it in 30 days.
Start with simple, safe wins that build confidence. Focus on non-sensitive tasks that give immediate time savings.
Day 1-2: First AI interaction

items: Choose your AI tool (ChatGPT, Claude, or Copilot)
Try this prompt: 'Write 5 different ways to say "please hand in your homework" that sound encouraging, not demanding'
Review the output - does it sound like you?
Pick one phrase to use this week
Note how long this took versus writing from scratch

blocks.text: Day 3-4: Email improvement

items: Find a recent email you sent that felt awkward or rushed
Try: 'Rewrite this email to sound more professional and warm: [paste email]'
Compare the versions - what improved?
Use AI to draft one new email this week
Always read and personalise before sending

blocks.text: Day 5-7: Quick resource creation

items: Try: 'Create 5 warm-up questions for [your subject] that get students thinking about [topic]'
Use the questions with your class
Note student engagement compared to your usual starters
Create a simple template for future warm-up generation
Save successful prompts in a document for reuse

blocks.title: Week 1 time saved
blocks.text: Target: 2-3 hours saved through quick email drafts, faster resource creation, and reduced decision fatigue on routine tasks.
Transform your parent communication, feedback writing, and daily messages. This week focuses on relationship-building through better communication.
Day 8-10: Parent communication system

items: Create templates for common parent messages (positive news, minor concerns, general updates)
Test one template with a real situation this week
Ask a colleague to review your AI-assisted draft
Refine your prompt based on feedback
Create a 'communication prompt library' document

blocks.text: Day 11-12: Feedback transformation

items: Try: 'Write encouraging feedback for a student who [describe situation]. Focus on effort and next steps, avoid generic praise'
Use AI to help with report card comments (remove identifying details first)
Test different tone requests (warm, encouraging, professional)
Create feedback templates for common scenarios
Practice the 2-minute quality check before sending

blocks.text: Day 13-14: Message polishing workflow

items: Establish routine: Draft → AI polish → Personal review → Send
Try message compression: 'Make this email more concise but keep the warm tone: [message]'
Practice tone adjustment: 'Make this sound less formal but still professional'
Create your personal style guide for consistent AI output
Track how this workflow affects your daily email time

blocks.title: Privacy checkpoint
blocks.text: Never include student names, family details, or sensitive information in AI prompts. Use 'the student' or initials only.
Revolutionise your planning process. This week introduces systematic approaches to lesson design, resource creation, and differentiation.
Day 15-17: Lesson structure templates

items: Create a lesson planning prompt template for your subject
Test: 'Plan a 45-minute lesson on [topic] for [grade]. Include starter, main activity, plenary, and differentiation'
Refine the prompt based on what's missing or unhelpful
Use AI to generate activity variations for different learning styles
Build a library of successful lesson prompts

blocks.text: Day 18-19: Resource creation system

items: Try: 'Create 10 practice questions for [topic], ranging from basic recall to application'
Generate worksheet alternatives: 'Design 3 ways students can show understanding of [concept] without a worksheet'
Use AI for differentiation: 'Adapt this activity for students who need more support/challenge'
Create resource prompt templates for different subjects
Test generated resources with students and refine prompts

blocks.text: Day 20-21: Assessment and review

items: Generate quiz questions: 'Create 5 questions that test understanding of [concept], not just memorization'
Try peer assessment prompts: 'Create a simple framework for students to give helpful feedback on [activity]'
Use AI for review session planning: 'Plan an engaging 20-minute review of [unit] that identifies gaps'
Create exit ticket variations using AI suggestions
Develop assessment prompt templates for regular use

blocks.title: Sunday planning transformation
blocks.text: Target: Reduce weekend planning from 3+ hours to under 1 hour by using AI for initial drafts and idea generation.
Combine your new skills into powerful workflows. This week focuses on sustainability and measuring your transformation.
Day 22-24: Workflow integration

items: Combine lesson planning + communication: Generate parent update about what students learned
Link assessment + feedback: Use quiz results to personalise student comments
Create weekly planning routine incorporating AI at each step
Develop troubleshooting strategies for when AI output isn't quite right
Practice rapid iteration: prompt → review → refine → use

blocks.text: Day 25-26: Quality systems

items: Establish quality checks for different types of AI output
Create review checklists for emails, lessons, and feedback
Practice identifying when AI suggestions don't match your teaching style
Develop backup plans for when AI tools aren't available
Share successful prompts with colleagues (with school permission)

blocks.text: Day 27-30: Results tracking and future planning

items: Complete the metrics assessment (see next section)
Compare current reality with Week 1 baseline
Identify your top 3 AI applications that save the most time
Plan next month's AI learning goals
Create sustainability plan for maintaining these habits

blocks.title: Success indicator
blocks.text: If you're saving 5+ hours per week and feeling more confident about AI assistance, you've successfully transformed your productivity.
Smart AI use requires understanding the risks and working within appropriate boundaries. This brief covers essential safety practices.
Privacy protection

do: Remove all student names before using AI
Use general descriptions like 'a student' or 'the class'
Check your school's AI policy before starting
dont: Share student work samples with identifying information
Include family details or personal circumstances
Use AI for confidential or legal communications

blocks.text: Quality and bias awareness

items: Always review AI output before using it
Check for cultural bias in language and examples
Verify factual information from reliable sources
Ensure suggestions align with your teaching philosophy
Test AI-generated activities before using with students
Be transparent with colleagues about AI assistance when appropriate

blocks.title: Red-flag phrases to avoid
blocks.text: Never use AI suggestions that include: diagnostic language about students, promises about outcomes, legal or medical advice, or content that feels discriminatory.
Professional boundaries
AI is a tool to enhance your professional judgment, not replace it. Your expertise, relationships, and contextual knowledge remain irreplaceable.
Track your progress with these simple measurements. Complete this assessment at the end of Week 4 to see your transformation.
Time saved tracking

items: Hours saved on lesson planning per week: ___
Minutes saved on daily emails: ___
Time saved on report writing/feedback: ___
Reduction in Sunday evening work: ___
Total weekly time savings: ___

blocks.text: Quality improvements

items: Parent responses are more positive (Yes/No/Same)
Student feedback is more specific and helpful (Y/N/S)
Lessons feel more engaging (Y/N/S)
Communication feels more professional (Y/N/S)
Planning feels more creative (Y/N/S)

blocks.text: Confidence and satisfaction

items: Rate your confidence using AI tools (1-10): ___
Rate your satisfaction with AI assistance (1-10): ___
Rate likelihood you'll continue using AI (1-10): ___
Rate your overall work-life balance improvement (1-10): ___

blocks.title: Sunday reclaimed hours
blocks.text: The ultimate success metric: How many hours did you reclaim for yourself on Sunday evenings? This is time for family, hobbies, and rest.
Your AI transformation doesn't stop at 30 days. Here's how to continue growing your skills and efficiency over the coming months.

blocks.title: Days 31-60: Advanced applications
blocks.text: Explore subject-specific AI tools, collaborate with colleagues, experiment with multimedia content creation, develop school-wide templates.

blocks.title: Days 61-90: Leadership and sharing
blocks.text: Mentor other teachers, contribute to school AI policy development, create resource libraries, present your results to leadership.

blocks.title: Beyond 90 days: Innovation
blocks.text: Pilot new AI tools, develop school-specific solutions, lead professional development sessions, contribute to educational AI communities.

blocks.title: Long-term impact
blocks.text: Teachers who successfully adopt AI report: 25% reduction in administrative time, improved job satisfaction, and more energy for creative teaching.
Remember: The goal isn't to become dependent on AI, but to use it strategically to reclaim time for what matters most - teaching, connecting with students, and maintaining your wellbeing.

tearsheet.heading: Daily AI Checklist
bullets: Remove student names/identifying details before using AI
Draft → AI assist → Review → Personalise → Send/Use
Keep sentences short and specific in prompts
Always check output matches your teaching style
Save successful prompts for future use
Track time saved to celebrate progress
Use AI for initial drafts, never final decisions
When stuck, try: 'Make this more...' or 'Help me improve...'
Quality check: Does this sound like me?
Remember: You're the professional, AI is the assistant
Celebrate small wins - they add up to big changes
